content:
13, 2016
												Here's my opinion about SK: PROS:- Great intro, one of the best I've seen so far.- The art style in this game is really good and unique. It's like a combination between Legend of Zelda and Chibi.  - Great, atmospheric music.- Solid gameplay.- Friendly community.- Shadow Lairs.- Intriguing story. (Can't wait for the other rank missions!)- Can be really fun when playing with friends.- It is indeed a F2P. You can obtain most of the weapons and the equipment and even cosmetics by paying no money. But it'll get harder. Trust me, it will.  CONS:- After you become a Vanguard, things can get pretty dull.- Game encourages you to grind. And by that, I mean a LOT of grinding. - Connection problems. (Note: if you're from Australia or somewhere in Asia, expect a lot of trouble playing this game.)- Can sometimes get boring.- Not much activity when it comes to content.- Price boxes. A CRAP-TON of Costume price boxes.- SEGA. Crap.FINAL VERDICT:I'll give this game a 8.5/10.It's not a flawless gem, but it's a solid game that can bring you lots of joy.And while I don't really play SK that much nowadays like I once did before (problably it has to do with the lack of content and school, of course), I can say that Spiral Knights has a special place in my heart.Met lots of great people, had tons of fun, joined a great guild (League of Gunners) and so on.So yeah, that's pretty much my opinion about it.I know it's not really detailed, but whatever.Thank you for reading!Yours truly,Mordekai the Summoner (Siliuser in SK)P.S: To all of my friends I've met in SK and are reading this,        Thank you and love you all, fellas :3. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .UPDATE: 13th of April, 2016 (I know, a bit late announcing this news.)Spiral Knights has now been bought by Gray Havens (a company formed by former employers of OOO). Spiral Knights has been finally released from the greedy clutches of SEGA.Let's hope for the best for Gray Havens and may them bring this once fun game back to it's former glory.We are counting on you, Gray Havens!

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												This is a torn decision for me, as I've played this game for quite some time. I've watched it grow and change with the addition of missions, guild halls, Hall of Heros, and of course...the bleeding heat system. More on that later though. For those who wanted a quick list of pros and cons here's my list.Pros  B-E-A-utiful world/Appearence. Honestly, the art style of everything from enemies to your sword is simply astounding.  Very unique soundtracks; Ominous in the dark woods and grave yard, cheery in treasure vaults, etc. This is my favorite part of the game acctually, to the point where I even bought the tracks on I-tunes. (Gloaming Wildwoods 4 life) Brilliant lore from history of the realm to the descriptions on items, small feature thats fun to look into.  Great community; come for the music, stay for the people, you guys rock. Easy to get into, not much of a learning curve, save a tricks that are hard to replicate. TF2 Hat included PVP is challenging and flows wellCons  Grindy: With the new heat system, you will have to replay levels to 'heat up' weapons, then replay them so you can get enough in game currency to buy (or just be lucky enough to find) the right crystals so that you can even continue to upgrade your things, just so that you can you guessed it Replay levels to do it again until you can finally afford to upgrade to better things.  Repeditive: While there is a plethera of enemies to fight, it isn't long before you can figure out how to deal with a certain faction very easily. And overlap (Or having two kinds of enemies such as Jellies and gremlins) is usually prescripted, so you can always know what you're facing. Not exactly bad for everyone, but the feeling of 'what could possibly be waiting for me next?!' is gone. You already know. Boss battles: Many of the boss battles are simply: (Wait for boss invincibility to wear off -> Hit boss -> Wait while he hides and a few bad guys appear ->  Repeat.) Though to their credit, most if not all of them have thier invincibility toggled by YOU with some sort of trick/gimmick.  Lack of content in updates: Most of the updates reccently have been a simple reskin behind a 5$ price tag of a "Prize box". They add very little into the game, aside from some more artistic things such as confetti, snowballs, alternate uniforms, cosmetic items, etc... They did add a few cool guns reccently though! ...After a year or so.  Little help for newer guys: With the way missions work, most of the mid and lower level missions are ever replayed after they are beaten, making it extremely hard to find a party and usually making new guys resort to acctually asking around for help.This game really is a artisitic experience that's AMAZING if you play it with friends. Though there is a point around3-4* where most players feel frustrated out of the tedious nature of replaying certain areas. It does take a small amount of paitience to play, but this game is breathtaking to me everytime I enter Haven. Give it a shot and see for yourself.

												Kinda decent f2p mmorpg that has no class limitations(hooray!)(and that game where i drained too much hours...)Community: In PvE, you may encounter friendly ppl(i managed to even encounter person that i love :o), while in PvP mostly complainers(those who complain about AT&T releasing too much of 1st in battle xD) or persons that make you turn into complainer.(As always!)Main review part:Graphics: Everything looks kinda pretty, but performance is not what expected for java and openGL...(8/10)Gameplay: SK features huge choice of equipment, which adds variety to the gear and gameplay itself(like you can use guns, or bombs, or swords.. or 2 of those... or all 3 xD) But because this game features grinding in big quantities you may get bored(or may not if you do co-op with your friend(s))(8/10)Controls: In order to rekt m8s you need to change much(like binding weps to keys)(8/10)Setting: Kinda variable even if its supposed to be under ground.(10/10)Story: It's kinda interesting but begins to be rly interesting only when OOO decides to release new missions xD(like those new levels featuring herex 'n stuff)(8/10)Late game playability: This game features much equipment/accessories/stuff that will make you grind it to get it. Also getting last prestige badge which can take up to 5 months.(7/10)Overall rating: This game can be very good if you have friends and you're patient, but if not then it's not for ya... anyway this game doesn't cost a penny, so better try it out!Rank: A (8,2/10)P.S. review got updated at 30.10.15 and game's rank reduced.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2015
												Overall, I love this game.  I have been playing since March 2012, with more than 2k hours, but I did not start off on Steam, so you can't see that. Graphics:The graphics are amazing, that's all I really have to say.  They are very smooth and refined, unless you have low graphics or graphics glitches, which I don't.  Both on the knights and on the monsters, there is detail, but not so much to make them realistic, which I think would ruin the game.Advancing:It's an MMO, be prepared to grind.  I have completed the game (mostly) so I don't have to worry about grinding, but there is a massive grindwall.  For the most part, I got over this grindwall F2P, which is possible, but it is hard.  If you want to get over this grindwall, I suggest grinding with friends.  If you don't have any friends, go make some!  This game has an awesome community!  As long as you're not a beggar...Weaponry:I will be rather blunt here.  Some of the weaponry is extremely unrealistic, and some of it is waaay too OP.  The Dark Retribution (the DLC bomb) is rediculously powerful.  It can cause massive damage in a matter of seconds, redering everything else obsolete, depending on what you are fighting. The rapiers in the game (flourishes and Snarby swords) are the only swords of their damage type, leaving you no other options, unfortunately.  Personally, I love them, but if you don't, you're out of luck. The guns in the game are fairly well balanced, but, as with everything, some are better than others.  Recently, the Magnus/Tundrus line has become OP, but before they were useless.  Pulsar lines are not as powerful as before, but they are still a good choice of weaponry.  The Antigua lines are situational: you don't want to use them against just anything.  Lastly, some of the weaponry is just terrible for everything, even though they look powerful.PvP:P2W. P2W. P2W.  PvP is based on unique variants that you have to spend a lot of money to get.  You also have to have the right armor, some of which is hard to acquire.  The weapons are NOT balanced.  Rocket Hammers, rapiers, Pulsars, Sealed Sword lines, and Brandishes are all OP, but some other things that are great on monsters, such as the Blitz Needle, are terrible.  Community:The community is very small, which is an advantage.  A lot of the players are older, mature people.  If anyone acts like a ♥♥♥♥, EVERYONE soon knows it, and they can be shunned.  The P2W Lockdown players (PvP) can be those ♥♥♥♥♥, but, knowing some of them myself, not all of them are that bad.  One problem with the general community is the noobs that don't know how to grind.  They sit there begging for money in Haven (the safe zone).  Personally, I hate it.Guilds are an amazing part of the game, which boost the community.  Guilds are groups of players, and your guild is sort of like an entension of your friends list.  You can do guild versus guild Lockdown, which can be very enjoyable, unless you are a small guild person like me.  Unfortunately, the guilds with the richer players have more members.  Wealth attracts people.  Conclusion:Although I have found many faults in this game, it is my favorite game.  This game has ruined my life.  If you are a player of MMOs, you would enjoy this game greatly.  I think I'll give this game a 9.5/10.

Personally, I love them, but if you don't, you're out of luck. The guns in the game are fairly well balanced, but, as with everything, some are better than others.  Recently, the Magnus/Tundrus line has become OP, but before they were useless.  Pulsar lines are not as powerful as before, but they are still a good choice of weaponry.  The Antigua lines are situational: you don't want to use them against just anything.  Lastly, some of the weaponry is just terrible for everything, even though they look powerful.PvP:P2W. P2W. P2W.  PvP is based on unique variants that you have to spend a lot of money to get.  You also have to have the right armor, some of which is hard to acquire.  The weapons are NOT balanced.  Rocket Hammers, rapiers, Pulsars, Sealed Sword lines, and Brandishes are all OP, but some other things that are great on monsters, such as the Blitz Needle, are terrible.  Community:The community is very small, which is an advantage.  A lot of the players are older, mature people.  If anyone acts like a ♥♥♥♥, EVERYONE soon knows it, and they can be shunned.  The P2W Lockdown players (PvP) can be those ♥♥♥♥♥, but, knowing some of them myself, not all of them are that bad.  One problem with the general community is the noobs that don't know how to grind.  They sit there begging for money in Haven (the safe zone).  Personally, I hate it.Guilds are an amazing part of the game, which boost the community.  Guilds are groups of players, and your guild is sort of like an entension of your friends list.  You can do guild versus guild Lockdown, which can be very enjoyable, unless you are a small guild person like me.  Unfortunately, the guilds with the richer players have more members.  Wealth attracts people.  Conclusion:Although I have found many faults in this game, it is my favorite game.  This game has ruined my life.  If you are a player of MMOs, you would enjoy this game greatly.  I think I'll give this game a 9.5/10.

												This is going to be a short review.Spiral knights is 3rd person MMO.In it you go climb down one level at a time, clearing it.While it does get really repedative (Which is my main problem with the game) the community is really friendly and the game is pretty challenging. (Which I consider to be a good thing but some people might disagree)Lets cut to the chase, Spiral knights is a game for people who can grind for hours or just have the money to spend.The game is just your normal P2W MMO.Although you can get most items by grinding, it will most likely take you hours or days for a single item. While the difficulty spike does rise drastically, SK keeps it fair and is pretty managable if you can play well.While all the things above are true there is also a great deal of unique items and events each year.The comunity is a very pleasant one, although it doesent exactly make up for the game's problems.The game is appropriate for each audiance as it does moderate it's chat. I honestly find myself sighting heavily each time I need to make a new item. It takes so much time and effort to grind in this game.I do not recommend it unless you find yourself having too much money and not knowing what to do with them.

content:
er 3, 2014
												I've played a lot of this game, way more than I would have liked to in retrospect. And I sit here wonder only what could have been. My initial attraction to the game was through its gameplay reminicent of top-down zelda games and its art style because, I admit, im a sucker for cute ♥♥♥♥. And while I frequently reminice of my days of old when the game was still fresh and new to me, I today am only disilusioned and disenfranchized to it all. I'll start by getting the good out of the way.As I said the gameplay is reminicent of earlier zeldas. There are a variety of damage and armor types as well as different enemy factions with strengths and weaknesses in acordance to these types. The enemy types are nicely varied and require different tactics to them. There are swords, guns, and bombs to use and equip. The arcade is essentially a sandbox element where you trek through different randomized levels. And there is good fun to be had when you take your first steps into Cradle. Then you hit it, the massive brick wall called "end game". A herculian task of overcoming frustrating RNG and tedium to get the 2nd highest level armor, then tripled that for the highest quality. Now that might not sound so bad, I mean reallly good gear should be worked for right? Well the thing is that its required to progress through the game. It's not fancy gear you can choose to get, you must get a full set of certian quality gear in order to progress through the story as there are missions that quite literally only serve as a gear check. And then you see the energy bar in the bottom corner taunting you to spend some cash to make the pain stop.After smashing your head against said brick wall for hours on end, or simply paying to make the pain stop, you are introduced into an end game world of freakishly overpriced fashion items and RNG prize boxes. This is a game where the endgame is cosmetic items, but due to the abhorent RNG and rarity of these items, they cost upwards of 20$-100$+ of real money. You can spend in game currency to buy premium currency (energy) which is whats often used for trading of these accessories, good luck getting anywhere if you dont plan to grind one single level and one single boss for all eternity. So unless you have enough money to smash your way into this impenetrable market, the accessory trade is strictly for veterans and no one else. By the time you have the end game gear, you have already done most of everything this game has to offer. That deceptive climb to the top was just padding. All but the shadow lairs which are the games only end game content that a regular player would probably enjoy. But those have an up front cost of 1800 (~20$) energy just to get a key to play one. And these lairs are just altered versions of already existing boss levels. The plot of the game is "intrigue" and thats it. You crash land on a random planet made of clockwork and machinery. Your goal is to get to the center of the planet, open up its core, and use its energy to get your space ship up and running again. Except years later, nothing has happened. Presumably all the knights were content opening prize boxes and killing giant jelly cubes to give any ♥♥♥♥♥ towards finding a way home. The plot doesnt move. At all. The core is just one giant carrot on a stick maguffin used to justify you even playing the game. The planet itself barely gets any expanded lore and when it does, its just there to justify new grindy content. Speaking of which, most if not all the content that gets added is a massive ♥♥♥♥ing chore after the first couple of playthroughs. But if you want the new weapon or armor that gets added with it, you will be redoing it nearly hundereds of times. When you dont get blessed with grind feasts, you get prize boxes attached to microtransactions so if you want the new fancy accesories, you gota pay up one way or another.PvP? Unless you plan on spending millions of crowns (in game currency) just for stat buffs on each of your weapons, then  you will be at a huge disadvantage. What I loved about this game is still very much there. The gameplay, the art style, the aesthetic, just the general feel. It's all there. But it could have been so, so much more. It could have progressed in really unique and interesting ways, it could have added meaningful content to the game to keep it fresh. But for now at least, OOO seem content to slapdashing prize boxes every so often to cash in while holding grindy content updates hostage despite being ready months ago. There is enjoyment to be had in the first moments of the game, but once you hit that wall, its pretty much that from there on. Thank god the community is still pretty awesome.

												On the outside, Spiral Knights comes across as some kind of childs Diablo. It starts out fun but soon becomes sadistic. content:
ber 26, 2014
												For the most part, the game is ok. You go through dungeons, level up your gear and rank up into harder areas, allowing for better gear. But it soon becomes apparent that there is a massive paywall to advance. Although it can be avoided, this leads to IMMEASUREABLE amounts of grinding the same either bosses or Arcade levels constantly to either get enough of the currency, find any orbs required to ccraft new gear to advance to the higher ranks and finding the ridiculous amount of crystals needed to level up your current gear 10 times so you can buy new gear... and the droprates of all of these things is so low you can go through 10s of hours without actually having found a single one.Another turnoff is that unless you already have them, there are 5 now impossible to get achiements, meaning you can't begin this game and aim to get 100%.The final downfall of this game though... is there is pretty much no endgame content at all, which hasn't changed for years, and very likely won't change any time soon, or possibly even at all, so once finished it may just seem really pointless trying to continue.In all seriousness, this game... if you like this sort of genre and you are going in with some friends, or you are great at making online friends, this game can be a lot of fun regardless of the insane grinding as the community is actually very nice for the most part. Although it has a  redeeming feature of its friendly casual atmosphere;  it can get insanely boring and painful to even bother, ...so I can't recommend this game. Should you play Spiral Knights...? It's up to you... either try it out for yourself, or just leave it, If it doesn't look very good to you, you will not like it.

content:
20, 2014
												A great F2P game, the game itself is great, with the storyline being where you can choose to pay attention to it, or just do the missions. The game itself is still in development with multiple updates having changed it from its original self, and I can only say that it's a good thing.There are 3 ways to fight, bomb, gun, and sword. Each one of these has its own perks. Guns can pack devastating status effects, fire several shots at once, and take enemies out at a distance (though with the way rooms are designed, pure gunning can be hard, but satisfying). Swords are just that, swords, they are the melee weapon of the game, some are your basic BFS (big fat sword), others are speed slicers, and others are status weapons for specific areas. The only downside to using a sword is that you have to usually be in the thick of the enemies to do the damage needed, and can put you at a disadvantage at times when needing to flip a switch, though the game itself provides jars to throw at the switches usually in case you pure-sword.Bombs are my personal favorite, while pure bombers are rare, they can be devastating when they are fully upgraded. Bombs come in a few different types, combat controlling, status inflicting, damage dealing, and shard. Combat controlling usually are the gravity bombs, which pull all enemies into the same spot for a bit before exploding, great for rooms with large amounts of monsters. Status inflicting bombs don't do a lot of damage, but the effect they do can greatly ease a fight, especially the frost bomb that freezes ALL enemies in their tracks. Damage bombs are just that, they focus on pure damage, they usually have quite a bit of knockback and are great for packed rooms. Shard bombs are multiple explosion bombs that come in a few different types that I won't go super in depth for. The downside of the bomb is that while other weapons have a basic attack and a charge, bombs only charge, so bombs can take an incredibly long time to charge without any perks, and you are vulnerable while charging.A great game overall, and its randomized floor system means you hardly ever do the same run twice.

												This is a okay little free to play Dungeon Crawler-MMO game. It might look kiddish but it has some degree of challenge. If your just looking for something to play for a short period of time with you and your friends give it a shot. Be warned though its heavy on that pay to play even though its free to play. You get a certain free amount of play energy each day and once all of that is gone you have to either buy with ingame currency,real money or trade to get more to be able to continue playing. Other then that its not bad. Its a java game so if you dislike java, avoid like the plague.

content:
2, 2014
												This is the best free to play MMORPG I've ever played.  I play this game direct from the website itself (www.spiralknights.com/play), that's why it looks like I haven't played much.  This game incorporates a number of themes smoothly into a fun adventure for gamers of all types.  This is a cooperative game that allows you to make friends and help them out, has a puzzle aspect in the levels, and the arcade portion of the clockworks is a genuine different adventure every day.  As new updates come out the game gets even better.  Updates aren't too far spaced and the new content is usually great.In conclusion:  This is a great game that is really free to play if one puts in the effort.  Don't take for granted the cartoony/cute graphics, this is a genuine challenge that is worthy of even advanced gamers.  Try it.  See if you like it.  From an achievement you even get a nice TF2 hat.

Its fun and fast paced with interesting enemy types and dungeons. With a building story. You get a pet that attacks and helps you which is also fun!.The only thing I would like is an open world. You go from instance to instance. You dont even need to go into the little town called Haven because you can instance from your ship to the mission and into the dungeon.

content:
er 30, 2015
												Spiral Knights is, as I like to call it, a "cutesy dungeon crawler". The game takes place in various depths of a mechanical planet that is always shifting and changing. With very easy to understand gameplay and lots of replayability, Spiral Knights is a wonderful game to sit down with for a few hours and slash, shoot, and bomb things with your friends.THE GOOD Easy to learn, but many advanced fighting tactics. It's free! Ever-changing and randomized dungeons in the Arcade! Everything you need is achieveable in-game without paying up. Paying is purely for cosmetics, or to speed up the grind a bit. Market and player trading. Trade items on the auction house, sell or buy premium currency with your in-game earned money, or trade for either between players. You can even trade items with other players on Steam! In-depth story, along with various mini-stories throughout the game. Lot of lore to get invested in! Weakness and resistance systems. Lots of weapons, armors, and shields for you to craft or purchase from others! A silly chat filter that can be disabled if you so please. A startlingly vast cosmetic system with costume appearances and accessories to let you customize yourself. Two PvP gamemodes - control points and bomberman. Rotating events with unique rewards! Unique Variants of gear that you can get as a bonus for crafting that allow for your gear to get super powerful! Many friendly and helpful players await in the game. Don't try to get them to play the game for you, but many of them are willing to help!THE BAD Depending on your location, connection to the servers might be horrendous. There are only two servers, one located on the east coast of the US, the other one located in Ireland. While you may get a fair connection to these servers, anyone with a better connection will almost always outperform you, which can make PvP gamemodes stupid unfair. Money = Power. You can purchase unique variants (they're randomized so you can't exactly choose) to make your gear very powerful, and there are no downsides to this the more money you have. In the PvE mode which is most of the game this is great, but in PvP it's an unfair advantage. Small dev team. Spiral Knights used to have a much larger development team, but in April of 2016 the game company was dissolved by SEGA. Luckily, old employees picked the game up and regained rights to it under the label of Grey Havens, and the game continues to live on. Meta gear. There are only so many good pieces of gear, and sadly defense doesn't matter more often than not. Trap gear. Certain gear lines do not extend very far at all, and can act as a trap for new players who haven't done research into their gear beforehand. A good asset to use before crafting gear is the Spiral Knights wiki, which will lay out alchemy lines. The end goal is a five-star item, so make sure your gear ends there! Very minor communication. Developer communication is nearly non-existant, and game masters are not actively participating in community discussion. Luckily, we've seen better communcation since the transition over to Grey Havens, but not to levels where players will always feel heard.THE UGLY Unobtainable gear. Certain items in the game were introduced in limited-time promotions, and are unique. The Overcharged Mixmaster and Celestial Orbitgun being the only weapons to have its attack pattern, plus its desireable combat stats only adds salt to the wound. Luckily only a handful of items of this type exist, but it's still something to mention. Overly competitive players. Certain players will make a huge stink about anything - and luckily these are typically confined into the PvP games. Plenty of nice and friendly people in the PvP games as well, but you're more likely to run into the bad apples in there. Progress walls. The game is pretty terrible at pacing the main storyline, and so while new players are racing through the first half of the game, they'll occasionally bump into progress walls. The first two are not really noticable, but the final two will halt all progress until you upgrade a certain amount of gear. These progress walls are only really a huge issue because of pacing, so if you don't limit yourself to the story missions the progress walls will be much more tolerable. End-game. Yes, the end-game is pretty lackluster. You aren't really given much direction, so you just fine-tune your gear, create new gear and try it out, attempt to hone your skills, or quit for a while. Doesn't help that leveling up your end-game gear is a rather large time/money investment, and that the best places to get the items for leveling up your end-game gear is in the hardest levels the game has to offer, meaning if you're new to the end-game it's kind of hard to be competitive.Overall the game has a lot going on for it, but time has left it a bit behind. Over 4000 hours in this game on Steam and I can honestly say I don't regret a single minute. It's simple, it's fun, it's cute, and it has really fun people in it. The bad and ugly parts aren't uncommon in games at this point, and if you just want to hack and slash things and have a fair amount of time to kill, this is a lovely game. If you hate games with grinds, you probably aren't looking into MMOs anyways, but Spiral Knights has very grindy moments.TL;DR - Game is fun, has a bit of a grind, and issues with pacing players, but at the end of the day you're smashes faces in for free. Connection to the server is the only huge issue, and if you can master your own lag, you'll be more than fine in this game.

												Awesome game!Music is great, storyline is interesting, graphics are excellent, deep game. Lots of gear, different surroundings, such as haunted mansions, graveyards, metallic cities, forests, etc. Something's I've noticed however is, the further you go into the Clockworks, the harder the AI becomes, so its important you get a friend or friends to help you. There is one thing that is confusing about this game. And that is buying new gear. There is like nothing to buy in the markets until you reach a certain rank. Then, your granted access to the Hall of Hero's, where you can buy recipes to craft new, better, stronger gear. But that seems to be it, as far as getting new gear goes. Overall, excellent game. 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 2, 2013
												[Re-Review] Okay, the big thing they changed here is that ELEVATORS, and CRAFTING items no longer require ENERGY. That's a WHOLE lot better. It made the game truly free to play. However, they changed their business model under the hood, and the way items level up in order to get people to 'push' on rushing their upgrades with their real-life wallet. They truly went F2P (80%-ish, I'd say). Swords, Guns, and Bombs are still there.ENERGY (the premium currency used for real-life cash transaction that can be bought with in-game currency as well) is still usable to buy stuff in the Cash Shop place via the 'Supply Depot'. It's mostly for convenience (Ex: to craft your gear faster with ALCHEMY STONES [in the old game, it requires ENERGY to craft items]. You can normally find ALCHEMY STONES in dungeons).In addition, they added pets that fight alongside with you, each having their own skills and leveling up mechanics. The way you level up gear has changed. It is both a gift and a curse. You can individually level up an item however you like, but when it reaches it's MAX exp required to level up, you need to get FORGE STONES to level up. You can either find them normally in dungeons (OR CASH SHOP! See a pattern there?). There is DLC that costs 5.95 called the Crimson Hammer to get more exclusive items just for that DLC, and there are these 'cosmetic grab bags' they charge for 2k energy or so (equivalent to 10~15 dollars give or take).They even went as far as to give this game a story and a mission system. Previously, gear was dependant on how much you've equipped. But if you're an old character with Tier 3 equipment already (5-star stuff), then you're omittted from these restrictions. New characters, however, will have to go through the MISSIONS in order to have clearance on equipping higher level gear.There's even PVP modes as well between deathmatch and territory points.This is at least how Spiral Knights should of been to maintain a high crowd status quo. The game is still great in terms of gameplay if you're into a Zelda-esque style. I really recommend this game now that the business model is fair.For weapons, Bombs are the most time investing items to level up, as they show their usefulness by 4* star and it takes 5* to really bring out their generous AOE potential. Guns and Swords are useable at any time, and their specialties grow stronger. Leveling pets? Very time consuming. Their potential does not show until spending 40+ hours leveling them up.I give it a hard recommendation if you enjoy dungeon crawling Zelda style, and aren't turned off on the video that you see.

content:
y 20, 2014
												I won't write a super long and informative review, so let's boil it down.Spiral Knights turned a new leaf a year or two ago and it wasn't so much a moneysink, as of now you don't have mist energy, lifts are free, and crafting costs aren't ♥♥♥♥ing insane like they used to be. Everything is cute, so in contrast to other hack-n-slash games this is great if you're a squeamish person. I, personally am not and I prefer to have my enemies twitching with blood gushing out is a reward by itself. Combat is a bit slow, but incredibly fun, especially with a party because the game attempts to swarm you with enemies, and it's cool to personally smack each and every one of them with your sword, bomb or gun.The thing that got on my nerves the most in this game are overspecialization of weapons. Each enemy does different types of damage, Elemental, Piercing, and shadow, and you can find yourself screwed if you show up to a level full of shadow damage dealing enemies with elemental Armour, and you're much more vulnerable. The weapon damage system is similar, enemies can either be very good at resisting a damage type or very weak to it; making weapons tremendously more situational and will cause you to grind more just so you can be the jack of all trades. The game as it is now has basically turned into Team Fortess 2 in the dress-up aspect except the game's content and enjoyment comes to a stop in a certain point because the development team doesn't feel like making actual new content and resorts to making Spiral Knights endgame a big dress up.A good multiplayer hack-n-slash that's being held back by major flaws.

content:
, 2014
												   A casual mmorpg inspired from phantasy star online. The pve is very much like Legend of Zelda: Four Swords, which can make for a great time when doing your dungeon runs with friends! The pvp game "Lockdown" can be pretty intense though, so if you prefer hardcore gaming then you may find it enjoyable. Another pvp mode "Blast Network" is essentially like an online version of Bomberman which can get pretty crazy, making for good times! Note this is not one of those games where you face harsh penalties for dying in pvp, if you lose you only lose your entry fee, and if you win you get your money back.   This game has difficulty settings for the missions so it can appeal to those of all skill levels. It's structured a bit different than the usual RPG, instead of leveling your character you level your weapons/ armor. Weapons include swords, bombs, and guns of all different sorts, each with unique damage type, speed, knockback, etc. It's really fun to experiment around and find what style suits you best! I'd suggest this game towards anybody looking for a laid back mmo to just unwind and goof off for a while.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2012
												20/05/2012 C.E.This is a game for all people. Its main aim is teamwork, as you can do anything alone in this game, but it would take MUCH longer. For example, doing a level by yourself would take 30minutes, but with others helping, it would take 10 minutes instead. I really recommend this game, except for the part where elevators charge you to use them.20/07/2014 C.E.This game now sucks. Ever since the main developer (Nick) left, the events have all been recycled constantly. With no new ideas, the game is stagnating faster than ever before. The only new updates are purely cosmetic modifications. (Quite less recently, a new system was introduced to make heating gear a little more complicated, but it was still mostly straightforward, until 5* crystals were made impossible to farm, forcing players to rely on energy more and more.)Also, OOO refuses to port to Steam for Linux, cutting off many of its own players. The game's suckiness has reached an all-time low.

												Awesome game!Music is great, storyline is interesting, graphics are excellent, deep game. Lots of gear, different surroundings, such as haunted mansions, graveyards, metallic cities, forests, etc. Something's I've noticed however is, the further you go into the Clockworks, the harder the AI becomes, so its important you get a friend or friends to help you. There is one thing that is confusing about this game. And that is buying new gear. There is like nothing to buy in the markets until you reach a certain rank. Then, your granted access to the Hall of Hero's, where you can buy recipes to craft new, better, stronger gear. But that seems to be it, as far as getting new gear goes. Overall, excellent game. 10/10

content:
y 10, 2014
												Don't be fooled. This game might have a cute and coloful look but what makes it a true gem is that it requires skill to master and plenty to keep the challange going while the COOP aspect adds infinite replayability. This is a true action game with one of the best combat systems I've come across. It feels balanced with enough variety to keep it interesting and engaging, but with enough simplicity to keep it from being unnecessarly bloated like many other games with weapon/armor upgrades end up feeling. Every enemy is fought differently and certain weapons work best against them. With all the different specialization routes like buffing up on armor, gunning, bombing, slow swords, fast swords, knockback techniques, precise shielding and dozens of different enemies on screen, it is truly rewarding to master.Although this game can be played exclusivly solo, the thing that really makes this game never-ending is the COOP. Technically it is a MMO but parties are limited to 4 players that must work together with different strategies to complete levels. Like any other game, it does have shortcomings, most notably the steep learning curve pertaning to making and using the variety of gear that is available, However, if you enjoy challanging action games with plenty of upgrading and COOP, you should absolutely must give this a try.

content:
9, 2014
												What is up with me and mindless grindfest games? Yes, Spiral Knights is uh, an old-school RPG for both casual and hardcore players? You might be able to see the part where the entire audience gets alienated by just reading that sentence. Regardless, After spending year on the game, I am willing to say that I immensely enjoyed the experience at the very least. Progression has significantly slowed since I started out, so grinding ahoy is abundant. Newbies grind so that they can get to 5*. The Vanguards grind because they have run out of things to do. It's rather clear that Three Rings is trying to do something about it, but their major game-adding updates are even less frequent than OVERKILL Software- And that's before we get into the mudpool that is what is a "major game-adding update". Some people think cosmetic boxes are. Others claim that chapeaus and tabards are not adding anything of value to the game. It's kinda tiring to listen to, so the gist of it is- Three Rings is kinda slow in development. Nothing any of us can do other than sit and play other games.So why play this game? Did you enjoy Legend of Zelda? Are you one of those modern day children who seem to have their minds in the wrong era? Well, Spiral Knights seems to be targeting people like you. The difficulty at first is easy enough for even elementary students. Midway through, the game ramps up in difficulty rather quickly. By the end, either you'll know how to fight, or you'll be stuck in Haven wondering how to beat the monster of the week. Back to the point, it's clearly not hardcore enough for veterans- Complaints of how easy the game is even on Elite difficulty are abound. It's definitely not for little kids as their first game- Unless they stick around the beginning forever, they'll start getting mulched when they start fighting in Tier 2. So that leaves you, odd precocious children of the future. You are probably a better match for this game than any many other people. Cmon, it's free.Well that's the bad, and the reason to play it. What's so fun about Spiral Knights? You get to run around and beat things up. In return, you get shiny coins, and materials to make better stuff to beat things up with. Oh, and feed your pet. Rinse and repeat. Explore the randomly-generated dungeon crawl. Find your favorite weapon, and when you become a reasonably good fighter, start using unfamiliar weapons because why not. Stare. Staaare. Oh, and there's beauty contests. I think. The last one I visited nearly got blown up by a hell raven, so I don't think there's any organized anymore. Oh well, you can dress nicely and people will wonder how you thought it up. That's something, right?Overall, Spiral Knights is a pretty fun game for a Free to Play title. The only problem is- It feels like it's definitely not for everyone. Or, it is for everyone, but if anyone tries to move from their selected space, they find themselves in a vice, unless they are part of a group that I hope is bigger than what my experience tells me. Either way, it's free. Go give it a whirl, try to be friendly to everyone online, and if you stick around, congrats. You might be the next generation of sour veterans who wish for new content.

												In short, if you liked Alien Swarm, you'll definitely like this. It has more focus on melee weapon combat than guns, though. At least, melee weapons tend to be more effective at killing.It's quite fun; all free, except you can only play 1.5-2 hours per a day for free (not including mist tank gifts). Well, 1.5-2 hours of being in a dungeon fighting monsters. You can be in the game buying/selling/chatting as much as you want.You can get over the time limit by going through dungeons and getting crowns (the ingame currency) and trading them for energy (which lets you go into dungeons to get more crowns).Anyway, you should at least try it!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 27, 2015
												To this day, Spiral Knights remains one of my favourite "go-to" casual play games in terms of adventure-style games. I think it's time I re-reviewed it.Gameplay at it's coreThe core aspect of any game. The gameplay type involved is a dungeon crawler, top-down view, adventure-style game. Think Legend of Zelda, in a mix of Four Swords coupled with Phantasy Star (Albeit very loosely)It has an interesting perspective, being not overly puzzling, but challenging at places and very atmospheric when it wants to be. Every battle tends to feel slightly different from your last one in some aspect.Unfortunately, there's one flaw with all this; The game's optimization is rather subpar. As a result, lag spikes do tend to occur at a semifrequent basis. It's unfortunate, considering the game is quite stellar otherwise.Gameplay-wise, the score is a 8/10.Artistic designThis game has a rather unique art style. It doesn't seem to stick to one general area, rather being more spaced out in several different directions at once.The players themselves, the Knights, are a good example of this. You begin as a knight who can look serious or cheerful, in a dark or vivid colour, that's either blacklight or neon, accented by vibrant pastel colours or murky, metallic styles. They look like those little figurines you can get, and can come in either plush, clay, or metal materials.The Clockworks themselves do a nice little background job, themselves. Each level seems sculpted to fit the design of the level and the family that lives within them. One family, known as Fiends, lives in an office-type scenario, with glyphs sometimes strewn about. Lighting wherever appropriate.9.5/10 with this one, only because on rare occasions, you get odd-looking pieces that don't seem to belong.Music CompositionWhoever came up with the music scores did an excellent job setting the mood for the area players are in. This is most noticible in boss levels, and tends to come to one of the most engaging boss themes I've ever heard. And this game's been released for quite a few years now.10/10 because I really don't see - well hear - any flaws with this one.Start to finish Gameplay ExperienceUnlike the core gameplay experience, this is how it can be, from start to finish, at a reasonable experience.Unfortunately, this is the only category where I feel it tanks at. It's nice and smooth at the start, as you typically get everything you need easily enough and can progress. When you hit about Knight or Defender level, however, that's when you start to see the reason as to why the game isn't as popular as it was or could have been.The main issue is the energy costs associated with acquiring the gear you need to progress. When I first began playing (This was one of my first Steam games), the energy system was Mist and Crystal energy. It took 10 energy to go down a floor. This is where my gears started to grind just a tad. That basically meant that, unless you had a bottomless wallet, you couldn't really play...unless you had an elevator pass.However, while the new system is better, it's not by much. Yes, there's no more elevator costs, at all, but there's now Orbs of Alchemy, which is the main reason why people stopped playing.I say it's better, however, because of how easy it can be to simply get a bunch of energy, especially now. You need 3 orbs of alchemy of a certain type to progress in the game. The one minor thing with that is the people don't seem to realize it's the same costs as before, it just takes an extra step, sometimes mitigated entirely if your luck is good enough to get all 3 orbs of alchemy while you get the 200 or so Energy you need for your weapons.Further, you need only ONE of your weapons at the star requirement (In the example above, 3 stars) to proceed, not the other one, two, or three. Overall, to get all 5-star gear, you either need to get very lucky, or cough up 3200 energy for 12 Eternal Orbs of Alchemy. Which, thanks to the drop system, is very unlikely you'll need to cough up all 3200, if even half that. Besides, some of the orbs appear as mission rewards.That being said, it's still a grind, thanks to the heat system rework and needed Fire Crystals to get the weapons up to the levels needed to progress. That's where I say not by much in terms of how better it is, but it's still not as bad as people think. One word of warning: Go full-out or you may find yourself experiencing Final Fantasy Luck Syndrome.6.75/10. As a side note, you can get 100 energy for a set number of crowns, which you'll likely get in 1 or 2 runs of the number of floors, anyway. It's honestly easier to get crowns than you might think.Overall EnjoymentIt's a real shame this game gets the hate it doesn't deserve. In fact, I think it's fair to say this is an underrated gem. Of course, every game has it's flaws, and I pointed out perhaps some of the major ones, the two big ones being optimization and the grind to get to Vangaurd rank.However, this game has some very fun moments, and at no point do you feel underwhelmed when someone brings in their 5-star gear to your party of 2-star equipment. That's the beauty of it; the game is balanced so no one weapon tends to feel super-souped up over the other, rather just gets the job done a tad faster.The only other complaint I have is that missions tend to be slow for release. But if that just means they have tweaks to them, or want to make sure everything runs smooth (See the Gunner Update), then I don't care how long I have to wait, personally.Overall score: 8/10. A definite recommendation of mine. This might not be for everyone, of course, but if you like what you see, download it and give it a go. The grind isn't as bad as everyone makes it out to be, though it is intimidating at first, and when it runs, it's mostly smooth sailing from start to finish.

content:
y 31, 2014
												This is one of my first and the best MMO I've ever played. You start out as a knight who just crash-landed onto a mysterious planet called Cradle. On the quest to return home, you delve into the unknown depths of Cradle, meet new friends, fight against darkness. Sometimes,  a jerk scams you, that hammer spam crushes you, the frustrations of others discourage you. But don't give up just yet. My friends and I came accross each other as strangers, in the end we become family. One day, you'll realize that home is not that far away, home is where the heart is.This game is truly a F2P game. So don't hesitate to give it a try. Sometimes you'll hear about a place called Lockdown, just stay away from that place till you're ready (to hear people whine, brag, flame, etc.) Let the spirit of adventure guide you to the very end.

content:
8, 2014
												It's free to play, but that doesn't automatically makes it a bad game. Instead, it's actually a pretty enjoyable game RPG style with a kind of dungeon crawler gameplay, with awesome soundtracks from the good old SEGA and neaty graphics.Why am i not recommending it then?Simply this game has been left in its state for years. Yes, there are some "events" for various holidays, with the same contents repeated every year, and always, ALWAYS new costumes/accessories/cosmetic armors, which are actually the only things being updated in the game. Stuff that must be bought with real money (like every free to play has to live with) that don't really give the game that replayability or wish to continue on in the game, because, we can also say, that there's also a cool simple story behind the game itself, but its simply half-done and the last gameplay-wise update has been done 3 years ago as a paid DLC.Now i don't want to blame the fact that, if you want more dungeons, you'll have to pay a classic DLC to unlock it, but after that you have the story of the game still left at half, because the game itself has not been updated nowadays, and you have basically wasted money by buying a piece of puzzle to your puzzle set that is missing many more pieces.Technically there are still some issues and bugs related to the internet of the player, since you need a stable connection to play and possibly decent one, even if you want to play by yourself in a kind of "singleplayer".Same goes for little graphical glitches, but i'd be surprised if there weren't any.Of course there is also like almost any free to play game something you can have to help you in the game, if you spend real money on it. Or at least you can buy stronger gear and weapons needed to progress in the game with cash, instead of in-game currency. Or some services to further improve them.Overall this was a pretty good game, but i personally feel this game is slowly dying as it seems the developers have left the game in its state, just adding some cosmetics to milk some more cash whenever it's possible.It had such potentials, wasted in lots of microtransactions.

												This is your basic Pay to Win crap.  I couldn't even play a mission with my wife because I didn't want to spend money on anything yet.  Which means yes, if you're planning on downloading this to play with a friend, you need to spend real money to be able to do so.  Or you could grind for 7,800 'crowns' just to trade for 100 'energy'.  Energy is the bane of this game's existence.  If you haven't figured out yet, energy is what you buy with real life money. The game mechanics themselves are fun, but the Pay 2 Win (in this case, pay to even play with a friend) aspect really killed the game for me.Grade: D This game had much potential, but the P2W aspect ruins it.  Not to mention the trolls and spammers.  One person was walking around just begging my friend and I to trade and spamming requests...I traded once with him, my friend didn't...but this guy didn't relent.  He just kept on trollin': running around us, spamming chat and trade requests.  This and one other person were in the Arcade.  I don't kknow about you, but I don't like games with $h!tty communities!

content:
y 6, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a highly unique action based MMORPG unlike any other. It draws heavily from the top down Zeldas but throws a lot of other things into the mix, such as Bomberman. With a good progression system, lots of unique weapons, interesting pets, and simple systems, it's a plain great game. Sadly, there's little balance to be found in the game and the developers aren't quite in touch with the community. The community is pretty friggin' great, however. The devs wouild gain a lot from listening a bit more to it.The game used to be much more pay to play but since half a year ago (summer 2013), it's truly free to play. The great majority of pay to play content comes in the form of promotions that cost Energy. Energy can be bought for real life money or the in game currency, "crowns". Thus, there's no real life money barrier between any player and pay to play content, which mostly consists of purely cosmetic items directed to end game players.Another thing I truly like about this game is the art style. The characters are space marine knights with colourful armours and really cool weapons. There's also no sex-appeal involved. Characters don't even have anything that tells you whether they are men or women and that is probably one of the things that contribute to a community with so very little sexism.Spiral Knights is truly a beautiful piece of art so stop reading this review and go play it.

												This game is the first one to get me hooked on for more than 100 hours. It's a very fun Action RPG to play with your friends, with various elements reminiscent of the The Legend of Zelda series, it has a huge variety of gear and equipment. The downfall is that it's rather become some sort of Pay-2-Win because the requirements to create or upgrade stuff is huge, but you can literally get almost everything for free if you are willing to take your time.8/110 would get 1HKO'd by sanic in Lockdown again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 21, 2016
												I love this game. I really do. I've called it 4-swords the mmorpg, because that's what the gameplay feels like. The variety of weapons is fun, and I like how your character doesn't level up- it's all in the gear. The visuals are beautiful and it's not the dreaded "standard fantasy world" setting that so many mmorpgs fall into. the music, too, is fun, and the game presents a decent challenge.However, this game has gone downhill. The grind for items is downright awful, and the economy is tanking fast. The playbase is dwindling, and the devs clearly do not care about this game anymore. I wish it was different, because this game was so fantastic and so fun, but the extreme amounts of grinding on repetitive levels has killed all the fun. With a heavy heart I cannot recommend this game.

content:
er 27, 2016
												Oh, this game...Spiral Knights is probably one of the biggest reasons for me sticking around on Steam, or at least venturing out to try new games. I've met so many great friends over the years, and while I havent played much at all in a while, since sadly the game is slowly dying, I still am so glad for all the time and money I put into it. The game starts off very cheerful and fun, and later gets much more dark and serious with the story (which sadly isn't finished. On another note, this game also inspired me to write a story about my own knight).Now, as much as the game has its flaws compared to newer, more popular MMO's, it's still my favorite and I would recommend at least giving it a try. It has changed so much from the when it was first released, most of it for the better, and it can be a great way to find more friends, not to mention getting a hat in Team Fortress 2.All in all, I'd try giving the game a try, especially if you have time to kill and dont mind grinding

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2012
												Spiral Knights is really fun as you're progressing through the mission system. The gameplay is nice, the controls are simple, and the stat system is understandable. Three Rings puts heavy emphasis on co-op play, and it is certainly far more fun with more people.Problem is, Three Rings updates the game slower than molasses going uphill in January with crutches. The only thing that can keep you hooked to the game is a desire(and the money) to do the Shadow Lairs, or a desire to play PvP and the money to be able to do buttshit in it. The only thing that can diversify equipment is a random Unique Variant system, and if you don't have the luck or money to get the best UVs, you might as well not play PvP at all.Still, Spiral Knights is amazing for a F2P. Just don't get overaddicted to it like I did, because once you hit the endgame, you'll be there with nothing to do for a month.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												I have played this game from its beta period and I previously reviewed it on April 24, 2013. Back then I stated that this was an "okay" game; worth some of your time but many of the additions made it rather annoying to play (mist energy I'm looking at you).BUT since then, I have come back to the game just recently and I have to give a pat on the back to the devs. No more wait-till-the-next-day-mobile-phone-gaming-crap. Vast improvements to the crafting of items and forging encourage you to keep playing. And the graphics are still pretty good, even today. This game has had a terrible past as oldies like me know. Having to wait for your energy to recharge and boring "NEW BOX!" patches being the only thing that was being added, as well as inflated crystal energy prices (anybody else remember them at 2000-3000 per 100?) used to make this a very "meh" experience. Though after my break of about a year from the game, it has really stepped-up and fulfilled the potential I always thought it had.6/10 8.5/10 This game really is worth the hours

content:
3, 2014
												Personally, I can't say much of this game. I quit the game almost early, because there was a broad storyline I could almost not follow, and the layout of the screen almost confused me at times. When I did understand what I was supposed to do, and (rarely) why, I would enjoy the heck out of myself. The graphics are still amazing for the game, but for myself ( who doesn't like when my UI is cramped) the game got boring quick. It quickly reminded me of my first days of WoW, and how I quit after a week of trying to get used to the cramped screen. Would not reccomend for anyone who is not used to the RPG feel of a cramped screen, but if you like a cramped screen, but would enjoy a more smooth and sci-fi graphical scene, this game is for you.

												Spiral Knights is a cooperative hack and slash with a distinctly cute visual style, interesting lore, and a character customization system that continues to improve. 												This game is probably my second favorite game of all time. The gameply is in stages cartoony fun monsters while you play a cartoony fun character. The game does get a bit grindy with 'orbs' if you dont want to pay money to get past having to try and get a bunch of rare rare orb drops so that you can get the higher teir armor. They havent really made anything to do afterwards, just a dress up RPG and look cool and maybe manage a guildOver all I give this game a ★★★★☆, I highly recommend this game.

content:
er 4, 2014
												I have only recently linked my Spiral Knights account to steam, this is why it says i have played very little. I have played 200+ hours off steam.Spiral Knights is a very well designed and addictive mmo, not exactly the most complex one ever, but a excellent game never the less. It has had many changes during the time i have played this game that can change elements of the game completley, some good, some bad, but not bad enough to stop me playing.PROSA Great Variety of EnemiesCustomisation optionsLevels (depths)WeaponsAreasCharacters (Npcs)Players (online)MissionsOther FeaturesCrafting systemGame modes (Lockdown, etc)Guilds (clans, groups)Great bosses and boss battles (Snarbloax, Vanaduke)(Fairly new) Sprites (Pets that can fight with you)Beautifully designed Stages and areasAmazing soundtrack (availible on Itunes and Spotify)Runs pretty well on non-powerfull PC's and LaptopsAnd much more i have probably missedCONSMay take a while to get/craft/upgrade items (not so much now after a big update)Levels may get repetetive (not in my opinion)Some missions can be very difficult (but optional)Probably a few points i have missed but this game hardly has any bad points.One of if not my fave game (ever)9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 2, 2015
												While the game is old, with updates over the past year the game has become much more free-to-play friendly than it use to be. Elevators are now free and there is no longer a Mist bar, meaning endless dungeon crawling for everyone. Leveling weapons is different, now requiring a specific item depending on the * of weapon. While hard to find at times, it is still possible to find the required item in Prize Boxes in through the dungeon. The newer updates the game have put the focus back on exploration and spending time in the Clockworks and learning the game at your own pace, not buying everything with real world money and just spending time in pvp. I have sunk easily 1000+ hours over the course of my time playing Spiral Knights and it will always be one of my most favorite games ever because of all of the memories I have made through the 3 years I have been playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a great game. Great story mode and I adore the graphics. Not many games have 3D cartoon-ish graphics to them, but there is one problem. . . Spiral Knights is dying and I don't want this game to die. My cousins told me that once you finish the story mode there is nothing else to do. So what I suggest is that you should expand the story mode and add new items. Back in  2012 Spiral Knights was popular, but now the population has decreased to 500-300 players. I'm begging the developers to please expand the story mode. Make an update that adds an more to the story mode. I really want to experience that feeling again when my cousins would call over Skype and we'd all play Spiral Knights, but because we finished the story there was no point in playing Spiral Knights anymore. Please expand the story mode and maybe add new items to the game. It's a big thing that I'm asking for, but there are many games out there that expand their story and keeping it fresh. The community is dying and I don't want this game to die yet. Please expand the story and add new items to the game. Keep things fresh and new.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 11, 2016
												First off: This is honestly the best free-to-play game you will find on Steam.The graphics are intuitive and maintain the perfect balance between realism and cartoonishness. The community is incredibly nice and supportive (hello, Dota 2?) and the possibilities to play with others are endless.One of the best things about this game is that even if you replay a mission over and over again, the scenario and map you are put into is never the same. There's an infinite number of possible map layouts for every mission, and the missions always have something different that makes that certain mission special and unique. Another major plus is that it requires no grinding/farming to achieve the highest level, and even once you have the best gear and have completed all of the regular missions, there's still so much you can do. There's room to have up to three games on one account so you can always start anew, and if you really think you've accomplished everything there is to accomplish on one game, you can always delete it and start again, opening up another new world of possibilities and game-changing decisions to experiment with.Being a Youtuber (PeaceOfMined), the guild and party options are incredibly useful and fun to record on, especially with the voice-sync (although it is kind of slow). The armor and sword combinations are endless, and with the battle sprites and all the different skills and compositions in one party comes a feeling that you're playing the perfect blend of Spiral Knights and League of Legends, where you have all the abilities and attack possibilities of League, and along with it have the intuitive control system, open-world feeling, and extra attacking options of Spiral Knights, as well as the manual team composition and chatting system.One last thing is the addictiveness of the game itself. I'm a full time student as well as a musician, Youtuber and athlete. What you may notice is I seem to have more hours on record than would seem possible with a schedule like that. I agree. Spiral Knights is a very addicting game. If you have a steady job, be prepared to leave Spiral Knights for a week, as you won't like it one bit.Me: Mom can I take a short break from my homeworkMom: Sure you've been at it for three hoursMe: *opens Spiral Knights*Mom: (seven hours later) Are you done your homework yet? It's past midnightMe: Yeah just a secondMe: *the next morning* Hey mr. teacher I couldn't finish my homework last nightTeacher: WhyMe: I was trainingTeacher: You were playing Spiral KnightsMe: How can you tellTeacher: Im secretly your friend on steam and i was in your party for five hours straightMe: subscribe to my channelTeacher: Already doneMe: Jesus christ what have you been doing with your lifeTeacher: Spiral Knights ;DI challenge you to find a better PC open-world dungeon crawler, paid or not. Comment on my Spiral Knights YouTube videos if you find one I should review. (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXN5MB1UIN1aH2FRw-rPV9g)Overall Rating (There's no infinity symbol on the keyboard):  infinity/10subscribe :D

content:
12, 2014
												When I started this game, I was young and innocent. I just wanted to buy Rome-Total War(tm), to enjoy the salutations of the people. How naive I was. Spiral Knights is an eldritch land, tugging at the edges of your soul until it gets hold of a jagged piece and rends you to the core, leaving naught but a torn, gangrenous wound in its wake. Any foolhardy traveller with the intention of tasting the Elysian nectar they believe this game to be, beware. For this is no nectar, but a venus flytrap, waiting, readying its gaping, ravenous maw to snap down upon your head. Stare long into the abyss, and the abyss will stare back into you, into your soul until it is nothing but its smoldering core. With these, my dying curses, I entreat ye, do not trust this abomination. They, the fallen, all said "Its just to get another game", I said these words as well, and I find myself here, hollow, not the man I once believed I was. Overall, 7/10 it was ok I guess.

content:
2012
												I've recently realized that this game satisfies a lot of my completionist tendencies, sort of like smaller games 'Upgrade Complete' and 'DLC Quest'. Not to say that Spiral Knights plays anything like those two - it's very much it's own animal. Essentially, I'd call the game a fast-paced adventure in dungeon-running, where the monsters spawn intent on ruining your day and your reflexes and gear are all you've got to defeat them. And gear - oh, the gear. You gather materials from the monsters you beat in the dungeons, and craft them into bigger and better weapons, armor and accessories. Which you then use to become stronger, rank up, and wreck more monsters. Plus, everything you craft appears in wonderful detail on your character: a nice visual nod to all the work you do. All this makes it that much sweeter to jump in, party up and make the Clockworks beg for mercy.

content:
y 11, 2014
												If you are looking for a fun to play game with cute characters and such, this is the game for you. This game focuses a lot on the co-operative play together with online users to clear dungeons and levels. It seems to be a very good place sociallise to other players but the other players barely speak much.You start off as playing for free and the adventure of you advancing through the multiple randomly generated levels of the underground to train and get materials and coins. The game has a very apealing toony style, from the infrastructures to monsters to the characters you are using. It all seems fine and dandy as you were expecting to reach high levels and be stronger than ever, until there is a level wall. This is the moment when you will realise that this game is sort of like a "pay to level up more" game, and not totally free if you are to complete your quest for the ultimate levels. In conclusion if you are looking for a game that you can team up with online players and fight along side with them with the cutesy environment and characters, then this is the game for you, but be prepared to spend a little cash to advance your levels as the game progresses.For me, I personally do not recommend this game since I first thought it was a full free to play and complete game. It shocked me that I would have to pay to continue levelling up, that totally killed the mood. Although it is a money making strategy through online games, it would have been better that they do not ambush players with that strategy and told them about it from the start.

content:
y 18, 2015
												Graphics - 8/10 - Shockingly Stunning - The game has a lot of equipment that draws a different look here and there, and lots of outfits and pieces to deck you out... But there's a feel, something about the game manages to pull out a cartoony, fun, adventurous look that just makes you want to play more and explore despite it's instance system.Gameplay - 8/10* - Spectacular~! Note*: Simplistic at best, hack and slash, kite and run, reminds me of a MOBA but an adventurous and rpg'like form. Kinda lacks in a sense for auto-combos which isn't customizable (Assign'ed based on the item).Community - 5/10 - Lacking~!? The community is lacking; I try to communicate, ask for help and furthermore and rarely if anyone ever communicates.Customization - 8.25/10 - Just play and you'll understand, You can change nearly anything to really own your "Spiral Knight", however sometimes forced to wear certain items due to stat limitations. A lot of the custom pieces to add to equipments cost a penny, or hard to get. Colors are there, only thing I see lacking is patterns that can be added (They have patterns, but locked on specific items/labeled items).Replayability 7.25/10 - The game got me hooked pretty well, but some reason I cannot find a reason to come back. After playing 3 hours straight, and 2 more sessions of an hour and a half.. I stopped playing, I assume it's cause at one point or another it feels too "Starter RPG-Game" to me, but nonetheless it's a notable game and I'd recommend it to all ages of my family and friends.Overall 7.3/10- "Great Game" - I feel what dropped it's rating is the sole-fact it's so simple to pick up, it's so easy to play, and accomodates everything you'd expect in a RPG.. However, it lacks a open-world, the discovery factor; Or something else such as a unique system of any sort to bring something new to the table to truly "Cling onto you".However the game does what it's supposed too- Very fun as it does, and can drag you on for endless of time if you don't watch that timer. Over and out,-V.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
10, 2016
												SK is a pretty fun game, especially to play with your friends (many of my friends absolutely adore this game, long after I stopped playing it). I quite enjoyed going through it alone as well. The graphics are cartoony and nice and the game is definitely worth trying since it's free-to-play: the music is ambient and airy and suitable for the overall techy atmosphere. As for customization, I really like the "main color" feature - where your character stays primarily one color that you choose at the beginning, kind of like a permanent identifier for them - and especially the equip-as-costume feature - where you can keep a piece of equipment as your visible headgear while using the stats of a better item (this way your character doesn't end up looking stupid because of mismatched gear unless you want them to). My biggest disappointment was having to go through endless grinding of the Jelly King in order to get 30 Jelly Tokens to trade for an item I needed. This is when I stopped playing, and I don't plan on picking up the game again, though it was extremely enjoyable while it lasted. Recommended.

												I've been playing this game, on and off, long before it was released on Steam, since beta.  I played opening release weekend, late March 2011.  One of my characters has over 85 1/2 days of play time on it, thats 2000+ hours.Great casual game:  +s, cute graphics, good music, great if you liked the Legend of Zelda games from NES, SNES, very simple combat style relative to most games.-s, little content; especially end-game, no raiding (more than 4 player, player versus AI content), limited pvp options.  Story is weak.If you're a casual player that can only log on for less than an hour to two hours a day to play, you'll find lots to do in this game without it feeling too grindy.  If you have more time to play than that per day, you'll get bored of this game relatively fast.

												Spiral Knights. A great, 3D Third person MMORPG. It's addictive and fun for everyone. When you're trying to level up, you do some awesome rank levels. When you're NOT doing any rank levels (or getting ready to do some), you do arcade missions. There's always something to do, something to unlock, something to buy. content:
er 19, 2011
												Never, EVER go near this game. IT has caused me an unbeleavable ammount of pain. STAY AWAY!!!!It is very much pay2win oriented, since resurrecting in the dungeons uses up energy and you only get roughly 100 per day (and each time you revive, it's cost doubles, so first it's 10, then 20 then 40, etc.).It is absolutely imperative that you live a maximum of 7 feet away from their servers, otherwise you'll have to predict enemy movement before they even telegraph it. Same goes for your own actions as you'll see your own sword pass through enemies unless you time it juuuuust right.If you DO decide to play this, remember: your shield is TOOL to be used often. Use it's pushing ability to scatter surrounding enemies away before they strike (again, have to time it right or you'll get hit despite having your shield up).Not recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
13, 2015
												In regards to Spiral Knights, I feel a heavy bit of nostalgia for Phantasy Star Online for the Dreamcast from this; be it the music, art style, or overall Sega feel. It's a candy coated, charming, and light action-rpg that I get an itch for when I'm away from it for a few months. However It's a grind for gear, and there's not much in the way of customization or variety unless you play everyday in copy-cat grind-y dungeons, or shell out real money. Which, I believe, the game deserves.  The paywall feels like it hits as soon I as get in a groove, and snaps like a rubber band. I eventually come back, though, for the tight gameplay and charming design. So yah, play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												I'd thought the game was a bit sleazy in its restrictions through the use of Energy back before it was acquired by Sega.Now I long for the day to have the game returned to a point when it was still worth playing! As a grandfathered in player, I was what seems to amount to the new concept of "Rank 5" or so, though I'm now forced to do unchallenging missions to collect the materials necessary to level up my equipment -- which I can no longer do after they turned the "Heat" mechanic from an XP track for gear into a 60% chance of outright failure to level-up with a rare item cost.After some 20 missions blitzed through last night, I still don't have the special "rarity" items to level-up my equipment, which has been stuck at whatever level they were at back when I'd left the game before.I could buy them off the auction house, sure, but now that the entire game has been unhinged, new equipment is either unsable (my rank is too low, where before there was no such limitation that I can recall), impossible to find (as there's no real benefit to selling what you can obtain by simply grinding for the mission handouts), or impossible to afford (as with 15,000 C, I can barely afford the 2-star gear I already own).If that wasn't bad enough, nigh everything can be obtained with Energy -- the magical, in-game currency you can buy with real money.  The game will even blithely remind you as you peruse your available missions.  Want a 5th copy of this silly shovel weapon?  It's yours for the low, low price of 60 Energy!It's the most transparent attempt by Sega to exploit the playerbase of a once-passable and admittedly clever Sci-Fi BMUP dungeon-crawling RPG to milk as much money as possible.I cannot in good faith recommend a game like this.  This isn't even the "freemium" the old game used to be; it's just downright disgusting.

												I used to play this game every single day of my life for about two years and than it became terrible. Don't spend your time to play this game. The recent updates have made it super grindy and by end game it is just boring and the only thing to do is grind for more money to get accessories for your gear which just makes this a dress up game. The only fun thing to do end game is to pvp which brings me to the fact that Lockdown, a simple pvp gamemode where you kill the other players and capture control points, is completely boring now because of the fact that everyone uses the same gear and people have became such masters that they are able do do complete 180 and 360 spins in about a split second and kill you. The only pvp gamemode that is actually any fun now is Blast Network which is a classic Bomber Man style pvp mode. The only thing that sucks is that now you can't wear costumes when you play it which was a fun thing to do in Blast Network because you could get cool bomb heads.
